This is not the only

as he had entered
Her cries having once tasted blood there
he was to return
a trap was made
which caught him the ensuing night
the fine was paid
the skin was given to me
The poor child had a piece of her scalp taken off
a triangular morsel had been bitten from her shoulder
her throat had a gash on each side of her windpipe
All these wounds appeared
as if they had been cut with a knife
none of them were
she had not strength to encounter the weakness
they engendered
Her father brought her in a canoe to head-quarters for the attendance of an English surgeon
she expired
as she was carried ashore
A party of us had gone to St. Mary 's near the mouth of the river Gambia
in the evening a bright moonlight induced us to take a walk
It was not very
we started the commandant a quaker lady myself to the outskirts of the forest
we had advanced some distance
My female companion began to think of danger
I in mischief rustled among the branches of the thicket in order to alarm her still more
We proceeded as far as a spring under a huge Baobab , where we stood for some time ,
where we stood for some time
till the monkeys began to pelt us from the tree over our heads
A slight movement in the bushes also seemed to say it time to depart
was
expatiating on our own fool-hardiness
then we went on
we reached home in safety
The next morning we were informed
that an enormous leopard had been caught in a trap close to the spring
half an hour after we had been there
his footsteps had been traced upon mine in the sand
We never could understand humanly speaking
humanly speaking saved us

waved from the hat of the commandant

Baron Humboldt relates a story of a native woman
a story of a native woman children used to play daily with one which came from the forest close by

Two of the early settlers in the western states of America , a man and his wife closed their wooden hut
Two of the early settlers in the western states of America , a man and his wife went to pay a visit at a distance
leaving
a freshly killed piece of venison hanging inside
The gable end of this house was not boarded up as high as the roof
a large aperture was left for light and air
attracted the smell of the venison
taking an enormous leap a hungry jaguar had entered the hut
a hungry jaguar devoured part of it
he was disturbed the return of the owners
he took his departure
The venison was removed
the husband went away the night after to a distance
the husband left his wife alone in the hut
She had not been in bed
before she heard the jaguar leap in at the open gable
there was no door between her room and that
no door between her room and that he had entered
she knew not how to protect herself
She however screamed as loudly
as she could
She made all the violent noises at that time
all the violent noises she could think
all the violent noises served to frighten him away
she knew
he would come again
she must be prepared for him
She tried to make a large fire
the wood was expended
She thought rolling herself up in the bed clothes
these would be torn off
The idea getting under the low bedstead suggested itself
she felt sure
a paw would be stretched forth
which would drag her out
her husband had taken all their fire-arms
as she heard the jaguar this time
scrambling up the end of the house
At last she in despair got into a large store chest , the lid of which closed with a spring
into a large store chest , the lid of which closed with a spring
Scarcely was within it
Scarcely had dragged the lid down
inserting her fingers between it
the side of the chest when the jaguar discovered
where she was
he smelt
round the chest
the side of the chest tried to get his head in through the crack
fortunately he could not raise the lid
he found her fingers
he began to lick them
she felt
them bleed
she did not dare to move them
for fear
she should be suffocated
At length the jaguar leaped on to the lid
pressing down the lid
his weight fractured these fingers
Still she could not move
he smelt round again
he pulled
he leaped till at last getting tired of his vain efforts
on
off
he went away
The poor woman lay there till daybreak
feeling safe from her enemy
then only she went as fast
as her strength would let her to the nearest neighbour 's , a distance of two miles , where she procured help for her wounded fingers , which were long getting well
